Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Real-Time Fault Diagnosis and Failure Prognosis of Next Generation Power Electronics Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advancements in wide band-gap (WBG) power semiconductors will play a critical role in a wide spectrum of power electronics systems and applications. Compared to their current counterparts, WBG devices are capable of higher blocking voltage, switching frequencies, power handling capacity and thermal conductivity, which can motivate migration toward electrification of transportation and a highly automated modern grid, among other applications. In harsh operating environments, these components are subjected to various mechanical and electrical stresses, wear out, and vibration that contribute to increased equipment failure potential, where a failed component can cause unexpected interruptions, serious safety issues, or easily lead to millions of dollars in repair costs. The proposed research plan will help achieve self-monitoring reliable WBG power electronics systems by providing condition monitoring tools that broaden understanding of the WBG device degradation process, incipient fault diagnosis and remaining useful lifetime prediction. Establishing an advanced reliability framework will lead to new scientific tools, accelerating deployment of WBG systems in grid integration, electric transportation and defense systems. The long-term vision and career plan of the PI is to integrate several thrusts relevant to this program, namely: WBG power semiconductors, power electronics systems, and fault diagnosis/prognosis theory as core disciplines. On the educational side, the goal is to develop educational materials that provide an integrated view of relevant fields for training the next generation of power electronics engineers. The PI will continue to reach out to high school students with tangible, project centric experience in his laboratory. The technologies and tangible applications developed as a result of the proposed plan will serve as instruments to inspire and encourage students to pursue STEM careers.

More specifically, the proposal aims to investigate incipient faults of wide band-gap semiconductor devices and create online fault diagnosis / failure prognosis tools to establish early warning systems for future power electronics systems. The rapid and widespread deployment of wide band-gap semiconductors raises significant reliability concerns, particularly for mission and safety critical systems due to limited field data and potential uncertainties. Continuously monitoring these systems is essential to prevent unexpected shutdowns and catastrophic failures that could result in fatal accidents or significant loss in operations. However, current diagnostic engineering tools are not mature enough to detect or identify failure precursors in real time, leading to a major reliability gap in WBG-based power conversion systems. In order to reliably move WBG technologies forward, this proposal investigates: (i) WBG device degradation processes under various accelerated aging conditions and failure precursors for use in early warning systems; (ii) novel online degradation monitoring tools to improve overall reliability using readily available system components; (iii) new analytical insights for fault growth model derivation to dynamically evaluate the fault severity level, obtain an adaptive fault threshold, and predict the remaining useful lifetime; (iv) an integrated framework enabling autonomous incipient fault diagnosis and health assessment for self-monitoring smart-energy conversion systems; and (v) secondary control/modulation schemes which minimize electrical and thermal stresses on faulty WBG components for lifetime extension. These tools will provide a foundation for self-monitoring, smart-energy conversion systems that can recognize failure precursors at an early stage and thus help prevent catastrophic failures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Summary

CAREER: Real-Time Fault Diagnosis and Failure Prognosis of Next Generation Power Electronics Systems 

 The work on smart, self-diagnostic systems performed under this project is based on a broad four step process as listed below-

1.) Comprehensive characterization and precursor identification

2.) In-circuit precursor monitoring techniques

3.) Remaining useful lifetime (RUL) algorithms

4.) Device/ system life extension strategies  

Solving each of these ?sub-challenges? is crucial to the pursuit of such systems and therefore our approach and outcomes are discussed in detail below.

Comprehensive characterization and precursor identification-

The first step in realizing self-diagnostic systems is to understand the basic failure mechanisms in power devices and how device electro-thermo-mechanical characteristics evolve over aging. However, by design, power device aging under normal conditions takes on the order of several years. Therefore, a custom power cycling test bench was developed to quickly age the devices under realistic conditions. The test bench is based on the industry standard power cycling test. It can tightly control and vary device aging conditions and is capable of multi parameter high resolution data collection. Using the test bench, a comprehensive aging dataset was developed for power MOSFETs.  Several device electrical parameters like device on-state resistance, gate leakage current, etc. were identified as potential candidates for in-circuit monitoring and diagnostics.

              Further, the study was extended to SiC wide band gap devices. Comprehensive characterization of devices from different commercial SiC vendors was performed to understand aging in this relatively nascent device technology. Several noteworthy observations were made in our studies. In addition to aging mechanisms observed in MOSFETs, SiC devices are also equally susceptible to gate related aging. This fact was leveraged to identify a potentially simple gate related precursor. From these studies, the need for an accelerated aging test bench designed specifically for SiC aging was identified. Therefore, as part of this work, a new SiC power cycling test bench architecture was proposed with accurate on-board parameter measurement and high precision junction temperature control. Characterization studies were also performed on GaN devices. Both enhancement mode GaN and cascode device structures were studied. Different aging mechanisms and precursors were identified in the two device types. The extension of the idea of parametric characterization to the system level was also explored. 

In-circuit precursor monitoring techniques -

Post identification of precursors is important to develop simple techniques for in-circuit measurement of these precursors. Therefore,several simple techniques and plug in circuits were developed for real-time and in-situ detection of electrical parameters. Simple circuits for threshold voltage and gate leakage measurement of SiC MOSFET were developed. Body diode forward voltage drop based comprehensive aging detection circuit was developed. The proposed circuit can detect and decouple gate and package related aging effects in SiC MOSFETs. This could potentially pave way for detailed understanding of the two different aging mechanisms and guide future device development. For current generation GaN devices dynamic Rds-on is a limiting challenge. Its characterization is challenging given the very fast turn-on times of GaN devices. Therefore, a dynamic Rds-on circuit capable of detection in < 50ns was developed and tested. System level monitoring techniques making use of existing system sensors were also explored. 

RUL estimation algorithms ?

              In-circuit measurement data obtained for sensors needs to be processed by algorithms to predict and warn of an upcoming failure. It is important for these algorithms to be accurate to prevent catastrophic failures and optimize operational life. Several RUL estimation algorithms were developed as part of this study. First, using the accelerated aging data, a Coffin-Manson model based algorithm was developed and found to be reasonably accurate. Further, statistical tools for outlier removal were studied. An accurate RUL estimation algorithm based on Gaussian process was also developed. Specifically, the proposed model uses Gaussian process regression (GPR) for applying a Bayesian inference (BI) on RUL estimation of the device. Using BI reduces the uncertainty associated with RUL estimation and leads to more accurate results. 

Device/ system life extension strategies ?

Lastly, with the knowledge of an impending failure, it might be sometimes necessary to extend system life till intervention is possible. To this effect, lifetime extension strategies for 3-Phase inverters and interleaved DC-DC converters were explored and successfully implemented.

Outcome and broader impacts-

 1.      The study could successfully develop a comprehensive framework addressing all the various technologies required for achieving practical self-diagnostic systems.

 2.      This framework could play a crucial role in accelerating the commercial adoption of WBG devices, whose reliability is a potential cause of concern for engineers. The contribution of this study is both in understanding long term reliability and developing techniques to prevent sudden catastrophic system failures.

3.      Several PhD, masters and undergraduate students who worked on the project are armed with the skills to address the pressing challenges in developing next generation power electronic systems.
